description:
Team deliverable - due at Noon

Post FINAL version of design review brief to Box by Noon. 

Post both a docx and a pdf file. 

Be sure the file name is meaningful since this will be emailed to the reviewers along with the briefs from the other teams. (project_name_DRB_date)
name: Post final DRB

description:
Attend the review session for your team.

There is no regular class session.

 

Grading info from syllabus

Conceptual Design Review (25%):  Experts from Northwestern and from industry will help critically review your designs so you can move forward with a solid foundation.  You must concisely present your project, and direct the discussion to gather critical feedback on the design and suggestions for alternative approaches, if appropriate.  The feedback and action items must be well-documented on Box. Following the review, the team will provide a packet to the client including the design review brief, a summary of the key learnings and action items from the review, and an action plan for moving forward. 

  • Brief:  The brief should concisely introduce your project and describe your proposed design(s).  It must provide clear support for those designs, such as user and performance testing results, thorough evaluation of technology alternatives, computational analysis, etc; demonstrate your technical knowledge; and identify potential project risks.
  • Presentation & performance: The team is expected to present the project in a smooth, clear, articulate and compelling presentation.  The team should encourage feedback and suggestions from the reviewers according to a prepared agenda.  The reviewers should leave thinking, “that team did a lot of work, advanced far on the project, and has made good, well-supported decisions.”
name: Attend design review

description:
Team deliverable

In the internal design review, you will demonstrate the progress you have made in response to the design review.  Since this work represents 15% of your final grade, you should have substantial progress to share.

Prepare a 20 minute presentation describing your design direction, supported by what you have learned and developed since the design review.  Also describe the main activities you will focus on in the first half of 384-2, to get prepared for the second design review.  Be sure to include the design process elements (listed below) you have been learning in class and through the reading assignments. 

As each project is different, you will need to consider how much focus to apply to each element for your project.  As you prepare your presentation, identify which of these are already part of the work you have been doing the past few weeks, and which elements need to be included in your plans for next quarter.

  1. GSEE Factors – Explain what Global, Societal, Economic, and Environmental factors are important for your project and how you are addressing them
  2. Human Centered Design – describe the key user touch points and context of use factors
  3. The Problem(s) – share what problem(s) you have identified, what you have solved, and what is yet to be solved for your project
  4. Design for X – Describe what DFMA principles apply, and any trade-offs with DFE and HF principles
  5. Evaluation of Critical Systems – Share your testing and analysis of any critical elements of the design, supported with functional models
  6. Key Project Risks – Identify whether there are any challenges that put at risk your ability to complete your project next quarter
  7. 384-2 Project Plan - Outline your plan for next quarter.  Address the points below, and include a general timeline of key activities.
  • What is known as fact to support your positions moving forward?
  • What are you assuming to be true in support of your positions moving forward?
  • How are you going to raise your level of certainty?
name: Prepare for internal design review

rubric.description: Did you demonstrate how your design has advanced since the design review?  Be sure to focus on the results of your work rather than a narrative description of how you got there.

Did you address the design elements listed in the assignment, either by describing work completed or by including them in your plan for next quarter? Be sure to only include the elements relevant to your project
Did you communicate the content in a concise, specific, and informative way?  Have you identified what you know as facts and what you are still assuming?
Did the slides support your discussion?
Were the slides highly visual?

description:
Each team will receive three progress grades based on the quality of your teamwork and project management, your degree of project progress, and the quality of your client communication documentation and project management documentation as described in later sections.  Assessment will be based on classroom observation and evaluation of project documentation on Box.  These grades will be assessed in week 5 (15%), week 8 (15%), and week 11 (15%).

  • Teamwork and project management: An “A” in this category reflects that the team was well-integrated, had effective strategies for work-sharing, followed a good design process, and maintained quality project documentation.  Project documentation should be detailed and posted as the work is completed.  While working documents can live outside Box (such as Google Docs), all completed files must be posted to Box and organized.
  • Design Process: The design process should include exploring alternatives, creating mockups early and often, performing both qualitative and quantitative analysis and testing of concepts, gathering feedback, and documenting the rationale and evidence behind decisions. 
  • Client communication: An “A” in this category reflects your use of professional and effective communication to keep your client informed of your team’s progress.  Copies of all client communication must be clearly organized and easy to find on Box.
name: Progress 1 grade

rubric.description: Have you met the key deliverables defined by your team?
Have you been applying the concepts from Product Design and Development text?
Have you effectively managed your project, including following and updating your Gantt chart, documenting your work, balancing the team workload, and seeking appropriate input and feedback?
Have you been applying concepts from Business Communication text?
Have you been working effectively as a team, including identifying opportunities for improvement and acting on them?

description:

  • Design Process:  The design process should include exploring alternatives, creating mockups early and often, performing both qualitative and quantitative analysis and testing of concepts, gathering feedback, and documenting the rationale and evidence behind decisions.

name: Write benchmark analysis report

description:
Team deliverable

There are two goals for this assignment:

  1. To apply the design topics covered in the class to your project
  2. To learn about design topics that may not be as applicable to your project, by seeing how they apply to one of the other projects in the class

Your team will teach the class about the application topic you have been assigned, using your project as a case study.  You will have about 20 minutes to cover both the topic itself as well as how you have applied it (or will be applying it) to your project.  Three teams from each section will teach the class on Tues, Jan 31, and the fourth team will do this on Thurs, Feb 2.

Content should include:

  • The key principles of the topic in general (not connected to your project) – 5 points
  • An overview of the role this topic plays in your project – 5 points
  • Some specific actions you have taken/will take to integrate this topic in your project and include evidence-based criteria  – 10 points
  • Relevant resources – 2.5 points
  • How you think it might connect to other projects in the class – 2.5 points

You can prepare for the class using whatever medium or approach you wish.  PowerPoint is fine but is not required.  Whatever approach you select, be sure to review the relevant section in the ­Business Communication text and apply the appropriate principles to your class lesson.

Delivery should demonstrate:

  • Application of one relevant principles from the Business Communication text – 5 points

 

Team topics

NU 101 – Relate societal factors to decision making process around prioritization.  Are there societal factors that influence how people assign importance to their different activities?  Think beyond obvious things like logistic involved in using a calendar or application, and really consider the things like societal expectations and pressures, the user’s emotions, and influence and pressures from family and friends.  How do you learn about these things in your design process and how do they impact your design options?

Coral Cleaning – In this project, you need to address both the labor involved in cleaning the coral and the water that is being used. What are the environmental impacts of using fresh water to clean the coral versus other options?  Think beyond the idea of “wasting” water, and really consider the lifecycle of that water.  What are the environmental impacts of using an alternate water source, or of re-using the water after washing the coral?  How do you learn about these things in your design process and how do they impact your design options?

PUMA – One of the key challenges of this project is the need for global collaboration.  How do you ensure you are truly understanding the perspectives of the global team members?  How do you communicate with the different team members to draw out the information you need, discuss design decisions and tradeoffs, and propose designs, in a way that is both respectful and effective?  How do you incorporate cultural sensitivity in this process?

Illumination – The device you create will be used in a medical research setting.  It will help the client if the device allows the research conditions to be as repeatable as possible.  Consider how this relates to design for manufacturing and assembly (DFMA).  Although the device is not currently intended to be mass manufactured, how can you incorporate DFMA principles, focusing on the need for repeatability (as opposed to DFMA principles used to reduce assembly costs and time)?   How does this also relate to usability of the device?

EVF to Virtual Reality – The context of use for this virtual reality device will have a significant impact on how it is used.  However, your team will have only limited access to understanding this context.  What steps can you take to truly understand the big picture context down to the nuances of a given situation?  For example, how can you develop an understanding of how a typical procedure might compare to emergency use?

Soccer Training – Since the training product could be used in a variety of contexts and will likely be subject to impact from a soccer ball, it will need to be robust to these factors.  Consider the journey of the product, including storage, moving it to location, set up, use, take, down, etc.  what are the different conditions it will be subject to?  Which of these are likely to be the most challenging to address?  How will you apply the principles of robust design to address them?
name: Prepare for Application Session, part 1

Relevant resources

description:
Team deliverable

Your team will teach the class about the application topic you have been assigned, using your project as a case study.  You will have 20-30 minutes to cover both the topic itself as well as how you have applied it (or will be applying it) to your project.  Three teams from each section will teach the class on Tues, Jan 31, and the fourth team will do this on Thurs, Feb 2.

Content should include:

  • The key principles of the topic in general (not connected to your project) – 5 points
  • An overview of the role this topic plays in your project – 5 points
  • Some specific actions you have taken/will take to integrate this topic in your project – 10 points
  • Relevant resources – 2.5 points
  • How you think it might connect to other projects in the class – 2.5 points

You can prepare for the class using whatever medium or approach you wish.  PowerPoint is fine but is not required.  Whatever approach you select, be sure to review the relevant section in the ­Business Communication text and apply the appropriate principles to your class lesson.

Delivery should demonstrate:

  • Application of relevant principles from the Business Communication text – 5 points

 

 

Team Topics

DIY Greenhouse – For your project, low cost and ease of assembly are both important design factors.  Although this is not going to be a high volume, mass-produced product, the principles of Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DFMA) can still be applied to reduce the costs and make it easier for the user to assemble with minimal assistance.  How will you incorporate DFMA in your process?  Are some DFMA principles more important than others for your design?  How can you evaluate your design with respect to DFMA, and benchmark it against other relevant products?

NU 101 – Relate societal factors to decision making process around prioritization.  Are there societal factors that influence how people assign importance to their different activities?  Think beyond obvious things like logistic involved in using a calendar or application, and really consider the things like societal expectations and pressures, the user’s emotions, and influence and pressures from family and friends.  How do you learn about these things in your design process and how do they impact your design options?

Coral Cleaning – In this project, you need to address both the labor involved in cleaning the coral and the water that is being used. What are the environmental impacts of using fresh water to clean the coral versus other options?  Think beyond the idea of “wasting” water, and really consider the lifecycle of that water.  What are the environmental impacts of using an alternate water source, or of re-using the water after washing the coral?  How do you learn about these things in your design process and how do they impact your design options?

PUMA – One of the key challenges of this project is the need for global collaboration.  How do you ensure you are truly understanding the perspectives of the global team members?  How do you communicate with the different team members to draw out the information you need, discuss design decisions and tradeoffs, and propose designs, in a way that is both respectful and effective?  How do you incorporate cultural sensitivity in this process?

Illumination – The device you create will be used in a medical research setting.  It will help the client if the device allows the research conditions to be as repeatable as possible.  Consider how this relates to design for manufacturing and assembly (DFMA).  Although the device is not currently intended to be mass manufactured, how can you incorporate DFMA principles, focusing on the need for repeatability (as opposed to DFMA principles used to reduce assembly costs and time)?   How does this also relate to usability of the device?

EVF to Virtual Reality – The context of use for this virtual reality device will have a significant impact on how it is used.  However, your team will have only limited access to understanding this context.  What steps can you take to truly understand the big picture context down to the nuances of a given situation?  For example, how can you develop an understanding of how a typical procedure might compare to emergency use?

Soccer Training – Since the training product could be used in a variety of contexts and will likely be subject to impact from a soccer ball, it will need to be robust to these factors.  Consider the journey of the product, including storage, moving it to location, set up, use, take, down, etc.  what are the different conditions it will be subject to?  Which of these are likely to be the most challenging to address?  How will you apply the principles of robust design to address them?
name: Prepare for Application Session, part 2

description:
In class, as a team: Create a Research Chart like the one shown in Figure 8.4 of the reading and record the key questions your team will need to answer for your project in the first column (Research), as well as how you might go about answering them in the second (Activities) column. 

To help generate this list, break the design challenge into the different functions you think it will need to perform.  Then brainstorm model products that address each function, and look at the patent literature to see additional options for achieving those functions.  Also look at trade journals and research literature.

Assign at least one research topic to each team member, chosen to cover a diversity of research topics.  Post results of individual research to Box by Tues, Jan 24.
name: In class - Create research chart

description:
Team deliverable

Print a copy of the student-client understandings form to take to your client meeting

 

For teams working with Shedd Aquarium, use this form.  Remember to get approval from Shedd before adding any project content to your personal portfolios or making it public in any way.
name: Print Student-Client form
